extracted_ttps.description: The exploit uses MMIO registers to interact with the GPU coprocessor, suggesting a potential vulnerability in the hardware or firmware.
Attackers may have used reverse engineering techniques to analyze and understand the target system's hardware or software components
The JavaScript exploit exploits the JavaScriptCore debugging feature DollarVM ($vm) to gain the ability to manipulate JavaScriptCore’s memory from the script and execute native API functions
Attackers may have used social engineering or other tactics to trick users into executing malicious code or revealing sensitive information
Exploitation of a hardware feature to bypass Page Protection Layer (PPL) and patch page table entries
The exploit's ability to interact with the GPU coprocessor before the operating system boots suggests a potential vulnerability in the pre-OS boot process.
The pseudocode provided suggests the use of a scripting interpreter to execute commands and interact with the GPU coprocessor.
Exploitation of a vulnerability in Sony PlayStation Blu-ray drives to achieve code execution by using MMIO DMA registers accessible through SCSI commands
Attackers potentially used command line tools like 'at', 'net', 'ping', 'reg', 'sc' to execute commands
Attackers may have used command-line tools or scripting interpreters to execute malicious commands or scripts
Manipulation of memory to write data to requested locations using a hardware feature
Attackers used unknown MMIO blocks of registers to bypass hardware-based kernel memory protection
Potential use of command-line tools for exploitation, as hinted by the discussion on accessing DRAM directly and using registers
Attackers send a malicious iMessage attachment, which the application processes without showing any signs to the user
Loading of code into memory using a hardware feature to bypass security mechanisms
Exploitation of a vulnerability in iOS 16.6 by adding MMIO ranges to pmap-io-ranges
JavaScript exploit is obfuscated to make it completely unreadable and to minimize its size, and it has around 11,000 lines of code
Use of device tree and pmap-io-ranges to determine mapping of physical addresses
The attackers used another hardware feature of Apple-designed SoCs to bypass the hardware-based security protection
The exploit obtains root privileges and proceeds to execute other stages, which load spyware
Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Screen Capture activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: MMIO Register Exploitation via User Execution
rules.description: Detects potential exploitation of MMIO registers to interact with the GPU coprocessor, indicating a possible hardware or firmware vulnerability
falsepositives: Legitimate GPU tools or software that interact with MMIO registers

rules.title: Reverse Engineering Detection
rules.description: Detects potential reverse engineering activities by monitoring process creation events for specific archiving and compression tools
falsepositives: Legitimate use of archiving tools by system administrators or developers
Use of compression tools for backup purposes

rules.title: Detection: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
rules.description: The JavaScript exploit exploits the JavaScriptCore debugging feature DollarVM ($vm) to gain the ability to manipulate JavaScriptCore’s memory from the script and execute native API functions
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Pre-OS Boot Attack Detection
rules.description: Detects potential Pre-OS Boot attacks by monitoring for modifications to BCD, bootmgr, EFI variables, and firmware update utilities
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration activities, such as boot configuration changes or firmware updates

rules.title: Command and Scripting Interpreter Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of a scripting interpreter to execute commands and interact with the GPU coprocessor
falsepositives: Legitimate scripts executed by administrators
False positives may occur when command lines contain similar patterns

rules.title: Detection: Reflective Code Loading
rules.description: Loading of code into memory using a hardware feature to bypass security mechanisms
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Command and Scripting Interpreter
rules.description: JavaScript exploit is obfuscated to make it completely unreadable and to minimize its size, and it has around 11,000 lines of code
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Inter-Process Communication via Device Tree and pmap-io-ranges
rules.description: Detects the use of device tree and pmap-io-ranges to determine mapping of physical addresses, which can be used for Inter-Process Communication (IPC) and persistence tactics.
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Software development activities involving XNU or device tree

rules.title: Detection: Use Alternate Authentication Material
rules.description: The exploit obtains root privileges and proceeds to execute other stages, which load spyware
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Process Injection
rules.description: Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection of Application Layer Protocol via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects Application Layer Protocol activity using NLP pattern matching, focusing on command and control tactics.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of powershell.exe for system administration
Use of cmd.exe for batch scripting

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information Detection
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate use of PowerShell for automation
Use of cmd.exe for system administration

rules.title: Detection: Exploit Public-Facing Application
rules.description: Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via command line patterns
falsepositives: Legitimate archiving operations by system administrators
Compressed file operations by legitimate software

rules.title: Screen Capture Detection via Process Creation
rules.description: Detects screen capture activity by monitoring process creation events for known screen capture tools and commands
falsepositives: Legitimate use of screen capture tools for technical support or documentation purposes
Gaming or video recording software that uses screen capture functionality

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

attacks.description: Basic user execution: runs the placeholder GPU exploit binary directly from the temporary folder, simulating a user double‑click or command prompt launch.
attacks.expected_behavior: The executable starts and would attempt to access GPU MMIO registers; in a test environment it can simply display a message box or write to a log file.

attacks.description: Intermediate execution: uses PowerShell to launch the GPU exploit binary in a hidden window, representing a user executing a script that silently runs the payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: The binary runs without a visible console, attempting the GPU interaction; for testing it can log a message to %TEMP% indicating it was executed.

attacks.description: Advanced execution: creates a one‑time scheduled task that runs the GPU exploit binary, then immediately triggers the task. This mimics a user scheduling a malicious program to run.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named GPUExploit is created and executed, launching the binary which would attempt GPU MMIO access. In a safe test it writes a confirmation file to %TEMP%.

attacks.command: echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "[User Execution] Script run by $(whoami)"' > $HOME/user_exec_basic.sh && chmod +x $HOME/user_exec_basic.sh && echo "[Info] Instruct the target user to run: $HOME/user_exec_basic.sh"
attacks.description: Basic scenario: creates a harmless shell script in the user's home directory and makes it executable. The attacker would persuade the user to run the script manually.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script file is created and marked executable. When the user runs it, it prints a message indicating it was executed by the current user.

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' > $HOME/Desktop/UserExec.desktop
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=Update System
Exec=$HOME/user_exec_intermediate.sh
Icon=system-run
Terminal=false
EOF
chmod +x $HOME/Desktop/UserExec.desktop && echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "[User Execution] Desktop shortcut executed"' > $HOME/user_exec_intermediate.sh && chmod +x $HOME/user_exec_intermediate.sh && echo "[Info] User must double‑click the shortcut on the Desktop to trigger execution"
attacks.description: Intermediate scenario: creates a .desktop shortcut on the user's Desktop that points to a benign script. The user is expected to double‑click the shortcut, causing the script to run.
attacks.expected_behavior: A desktop entry file and accompanying script are created. When the user activates the shortcut, the script runs and prints a confirmation message.

attacks.command: echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "[User Execution] pkexec script executed as $(whoami)"' > $HOME/user_exec_advanced.sh && chmod +x $HOME/user_exec_advanced.sh && pkexec $HOME/user_exec_advanced.sh
attacks.description: Advanced scenario: creates a script and executes it via pkexec, which presents an authentication dialog. The user must approve the prompt, demonstrating user‑driven execution with privilege escalation potential.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is created and then launched with pkexec. A graphical authentication prompt appears; after the user approves, the script runs and outputs its execution identity.

attacks.description: Gather system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt window.

attacks.description: List installed device drivers
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all installed device drivers in the command prompt window.

attacks.description: Collect detailed system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a window displaying detailed system information, including hardware, software, and system components.

attacks.description: Basic command to gather information about the CPU architecture.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays information about the CPU, including the architecture, vendor ID, model, and flags.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to list loaded kernel modules.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the loaded kernel modules, which can provide insights into the system's hardware and software capabilities.

attacks.description: Advanced command requiring admin privileges to extract BIOS information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about the system's BIOS, including the version, vendor, and release date, which can be useful for reverse engineering purposes.

attacks.description: Writes a minimal JavaScript file containing a placeholder for the $vm exploit and executes it with Windows Script Host.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named exploit.js is created in the TEMP directory containing a comment line. cscript runs the file, which does nothing harmful and exits without error.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\exploit_adv.js\" -Value '// Exploit code placeholder`nfunction exploit(){ /* placeholder for $vm manipulation */ }' -Encoding ASCII; & cscript //nologo \"$env:TEMP\exploit_adv.js\""
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to create a multi‑line JavaScript file with a placeholder exploit function, then runs it via cscript.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script writes exploit_adv.js to the TEMP folder containing a comment and a dummy function. cscript executes the file; no malicious activity occurs, and the command returns cleanly.

attacks.command: echo // Exploit code placeholder > %TEMP%\exploit_schtask.js && schtasks /Create /TN "JSCExploit" /TR "cscript //nologo %TEMP%\exploit_schtask.js" /SC ONSTART /RL HIGHEST /F
attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs the placeholder JavaScript exploit at system startup with highest privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file exploit_schtask.js is created in TEMP containing a comment. schtasks registers a task named JSCExploit that will invoke cscript on the file each boot with elevated rights. The task creation succeeds; the script itself is benign.

attacks.description: Compile an exploit using gcc, assuming the exploit code is in exploit.c. This command demonstrates the basic concept of preparing an exploit for execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The exploit is compiled and ready for execution, potentially leading to privilege escalation if successfully exploited.

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { system("/bin/sh"); return 0; }' > exploit.c; gcc -o exploit exploit.c; ./exploit
attacks.description: This intermediate command creates a simple C program that executes a shell, compiles it, and then runs it. This demonstrates creating and executing a basic exploit that could lead to privilege escalation if the shell is executed with elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A shell is executed, potentially with elevated privileges if the exploit is successful.

attacks.description: This advanced command demonstrates exploiting a vulnerability in a program by running it with the privileges of a user who has access to sensitive resources. The exploit would be tailored to the specific vulnerability in the program.
attacks.expected_behavior: The exploitable program is executed with the privileges of the specified user, potentially leading to privilege escalation or access to sensitive resources if the exploit is successful.

attacks.description: Basic modification of the Boot Configuration Data to ignore all boot failures, demonstrating influence over the pre‑OS boot process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The boot manager will no longer halt on boot failures; the system will continue booting even if later stages encounter errors.

attacks.command: bcdedit /create {9e2b5c7d-1234-5678-9abc-def012345678} /d "GPU Test Loader" /application BOOTAPP && bcdedit /set {9e2b5c7d-1234-5678-9abc-def012345678} device partition=C: && bcdedit /set {9e2b5c7d-1234-5678-9abc-def012345678} path \Windows\System32\drivers\gpuload.sys && bcdedit /displayorder {9e2b5c7d-1234-5678-9abc-def012345678} /addlast
attacks.description: Intermediate creation of a custom BCD boot entry that references a placeholder GPU driver (gpuload.sys) to be loaded during the pre‑OS stage.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new boot entry appears in the boot menu; if selected, the system will attempt to load gpuload.sys before the OS starts. Because the driver is a placeholder, loading will fail gracefully without system damage.

attacks.command: sc create GPULoader binPath= "%SystemRoot%\System32\drivers\gpuload.sys" type= kernel start= boot && sc start GPULoader
attacks.description: Advanced registration of a kernel‑mode service that is configured to start at boot, representing a driver that could interact with the GPU before user‑mode components load.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Service Control Manager registers a kernel driver named GPULoader set to start during the boot phase. Starting the service now will load the driver into kernel space; if the driver file is absent, the start command will fail but no persistent damage occurs.

attacks.description: Adds a custom GRUB menu entry that boots a dummy kernel with a custom initrd, simulating pre-OS GPU interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: The GRUB configuration is updated; a new menu entry appears on next reboot. No actual kernel or GPU code is executed during the test.

attacks.description: Basic use of the Windows command interpreter to create a text file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named basic.txt containing 'Hello World' is created in the %TEMP% folder.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell script that queries GPU (video controller) information via WMI and writes the result as JSON to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named gpu_info.json is created in %TEMP% containing JSON-formatted details about the system's video controller(s).

attacks.description: Advanced use of PowerShell to launch a secondary cmd.exe process that writes a file, demonstrating process creation via a scripting interpreter.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named advanced.txt containing 'Advanced Execution' is created in the %TEMP% directory after the secondary cmd.exe process completes.

attacks.description: Executes a simple echo statement via the Bash interpreter to demonstrate basic command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the message 'Basic interpreter test:' followed by the current date and time to standard output.

attacks.description: Uses the sh interpreter to run nvidia-smi, querying GPU name and driver version in CSV format.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a CSV line containing the GPU name and driver version, or an error message if the NVIDIA driver is not present.

attacks.description: Executes Bash with elevated privileges to load the NVIDIA kernel module using modprobe, demonstrating privileged interpreter usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to load the 'nvidia' kernel module, printing verbose information about the module loading process; succeeds only if run as root and the module exists.

attacks.description: Creates a dummy DLL from a base64 string, decodes it to a file in %TEMP%, and loads it into memory using rundll32.exe (basic reflective loading).
attacks.expected_behavior: The dummy DLL is written to disk, decoded, and then executed in memory by rundll32.exe, demonstrating reflective code loading without invoking a separate installer.

attacks.description: Loads the previously created dummy DLL using regsvr32.exe with the /i switch, providing an alternative reflective loading mechanism.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32.exe loads the DLL into the process space of regsvr32, executing its entry point without writing additional files, showcasing reflective loading via a different system binary.

attacks.command: sc.exe create ReflectiveSvc binPath= "rundll32.exe %TEMP%\reflect.dll,EntryPoint" start= demand && sc.exe start ReflectiveSvc
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service that runs the dummy DLL via rundll32.exe and starts the service, demonstrating advanced reflective loading with persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named ReflectiveSvc is registered; when started, it loads the DLL into memory using rundll32.exe, illustrating reflective code execution in a privileged context.

attacks.command: LD_PRELOAD=$(mktemp -p /dev/shm libXXXX.so); cat /tmp/benign_payload.so > "$LD_PRELOAD"; /usr/bin/env -i LD_PRELOAD="$LD_PRELOAD" /bin/bash -c 'echo "Reflective library loaded from memory"'
attacks.description: Creates a temporary in‑memory file in /dev/shm, copies a benign shared object into it, and launches a new bash process with LD_PRELOAD pointing to that in‑memory library, causing the library to be reflected into the process address space.
attacks.expected_behavior: The bash process starts and prints the message, indicating the library was preloaded from the memory‑backed file. No persistent files are written to disk.

attacks.command: exec {fd}>$(mktemp -p /dev/shm memfdXXXX); cat /tmp/benign_payload.so >&$fd; LD_PRELOAD=/proc/self/fd/$fd /bin/bash -c 'echo "Loaded via memfd file descriptor"'
attacks.description: Creates a temporary file descriptor backed by a file in /dev/shm, writes a shared object into it, and then uses LD_PRELOAD with the /proc/self/fd path to load the library directly from the open file descriptor, achieving reflective loading without a named file on disk.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new bash process runs and outputs the confirmation message, showing that the library was loaded via the in‑memory file descriptor.

attacks.description: Copies a benign shared object to the memory‑backed /dev/shm filesystem and then invokes the dynamic loader (ld-linux) with LD_LIBRARY_PATH pointing to that location, causing the library to be reflected into the loader's process space during execution of /bin/true.
attacks.expected_behavior: The /bin/true command executes silently; the loader loads the library from /dev/shm, demonstrating reflective loading from a RAM‑disk location.

attacks.description: Creates a minimal JavaScript file with a placeholder comment and executes it using cscript.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obf.js is written to the temporary directory containing a comment. cscript runs the script, which produces no output but demonstrates execution of a JavaScript interpreter.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to generate a larger, obfuscated‑looking JavaScript file (10k characters) and runs it with cscript.
attacks.expected_behavior: A 10,000‑character JavaScript file is created in the temp folder. cscript executes the file, again producing no visible output but confirming that a sizable script can be run.

attacks.description: Writes a Base64‑encoded JavaScript payload to a file, decodes it with certutil, and executes the resulting script via cscript.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Base64 string decodes to a comment (/* Obfuscated JS code */). The decoded file is saved as obf.js and executed with cscript, demonstrating the use of encoding/decoding steps before script execution.

attacks.description: Basic: Write a small obfuscated JavaScript file to /tmp and execute it with node. The script uses hex‑escaped strings to hide the 'Hello' message.
attacks.expected_behavior: The node process runs and prints 'Hello' to stdout, demonstrating execution of an obfuscated JavaScript interpreter payload.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Store an obfuscated JavaScript payload as a base64 string, decode it to a temporary file, make it executable, and run it with node. The payload prints 'Hello' using escaped characters.
attacks.expected_behavior: Node executes the decoded script and outputs 'Hello' to the console, showing that a hidden payload can be delivered via base64 encoding and then interpreted.

attacks.description: Advanced: Execute an obfuscated JavaScript one‑liner directly via node -e, constructing object property names and the message using hex escapes to hide intent.
attacks.expected_behavior: The inline script runs and prints 'Hello' without creating any files, demonstrating in‑memory obfuscation and execution of JavaScript code.

attacks.description: Query the system device tree from the registry and write the full output to a temporary file for later consumption by another process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\device_tree.txt containing the registry entries under HKLM\HARDWARE\DEVICEMAP\Scsi.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_DeviceMemoryAddress | Select-Object StartingAddress, EndingAddress, Description | Out-File -FilePath $env:TEMP\mem_ranges.txt -Encoding ASCII"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to retrieve physical memory address ranges via the Win32_DeviceMemoryAddress WMI class and store them in a temporary text file for inter‑process sharing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\mem_ranges.txt listing start/end addresses and descriptions of memory-mapped devices.

attacks.description: Filter the device tree registry output for lines containing the word "Physical" and write the filtered results to a temporary file, simulating IPC via a shared file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\phys_addresses.txt containing only entries that reference physical addresses.

attacks.description: Basic enumeration of the device‑tree entries to discover available hardware nodes and their properties.
attacks.expected_behavior: Recursively lists the files and directories under /proc/device-tree, showing node names such as soc, serial@..., etc., without producing errors for inaccessible entries.

attacks.description: Intermediate use of pmap to display the memory map of the systemd process, filtering for I/O‑related regions that may correspond to device mappings.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the memory map of the systemd process with address ranges, permissions, and size, highlighting any entries that contain 'io' in their description.

attacks.command: addr=$(od -An -t x4 /proc/device-tree/soc/serial@0x20201000/reg | tr -d ' \n'); echo "Device address: 0x$addr"; pmap -x $(pidof systemd) | grep "0x$addr"
attacks.description: Advanced correlation: extracts the physical address of a serial device from the device‑tree, then searches the memory map of systemd for a matching address, demonstrating IPC through shared physical mappings.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the extracted device address (e.g., 0x20201000) and then shows any lines in systemd's pmap output that contain that address, indicating a possible shared mapping.

attacks.description: Stores alternate authentication material (username and password) for the target host 'example.com' in the Windows Credential Manager using the built‑in cmdkey utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new generic credential entry for 'example.com' is created; subsequent network connections to that host will automatically use the supplied TestUser/Password123 credentials.

attacks.description: Executes PowerShell under alternate credentials using the /netonly switch, which forces network authentication to use the supplied TestUser while keeping the local process context unchanged.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell launches and runs 'whoami /all', displaying the local user token; however, any outbound network calls from this session will be authenticated as TestUser.

attacks.command: schtasks /Create /SC ONCE /ST 23:59 /TN "AltCredTask" /TR "cmd.exe /c echo Test > \"%TEMP%\\altcred.txt\"" /RU TestUser /RP Password123
attacks.description: Creates a one‑time scheduled task that runs a benign command (writes a test file) using the alternate credentials TestUser/Password123, demonstrating persistence with alternate authentication material.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'AltCredTask' is registered; when triggered at 23:59 it executes the command, resulting in a file 'altcred.txt' containing the word 'Test' in the user's temporary directory, running under the TestUser context.

attacks.description: Basic example using sudo to switch to the root user and create a test file, simulating the use of alternate authentication material to gain elevated access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Test Alternate Auth', demonstrating the use of sudo for elevated access.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using pkexec to execute a command as another user (potentially root), creating a file to test detection of alternate authentication material usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named intermediate_test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Intermediate Test', showing the use of pkexec for executing commands with elevated privileges.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "Advanced Alternate Auth Test" > /tmp/advanced_test.txt && chmod 600 /tmp/advanced_test.txt'
attacks.description: Advanced example using sudo to run a bash command that creates a file and then changes its permissions, simulating advanced usage of alternate authentication material for gaining access and modifying system files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named advanced_test.txt in /tmp with the content 'Advanced Alternate Auth Test' and then changes the file's permissions to 600, demonstrating the use of sudo for complex operations involving file creation and modification.

attacks.description: Loads a benign DLL into a new rundll32 process using the DummyEntry export, demonstrating basic process injection via DLL loading.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new rundll32.exe process starts, loads the specified DLL, and executes the DummyEntry function. No persistent changes are made.

attacks.description: Registers a benign DLL with regsvr32 using the /i switch, causing the DLL to be loaded into a COM host process, illustrating intermediate process injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32 silently registers the DLL and loads it into a COM host (e.g., dllhost.exe). The DLL's DllRegisterServer entry runs, but no permanent registration is created due to /n.

attacks.command: sc.exe create InjectService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\Temp\\injector.exe" start= demand && sc.exe start InjectService
attacks.description: Creates and starts a Windows service that runs a custom executable designed to perform process injection into a target system process. This demonstrates an advanced, privilege‑escalated injection technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named InjectService is registered with the system and started. The placeholder injector.exe runs under the service's context (typically SYSTEM) and can inject code into other processes. The service can be removed after testing.

attacks.description: Launches a new sleep process with a dummy shared library preloaded using LD_PRELOAD, demonstrating basic process injection at process creation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A sleep process runs for 60 seconds with the fake.so library loaded; no visible effect on the system.

attacks.description: Attaches gdb to an existing sleep process and invokes dlopen to inject the dummy shared library into its address space.
attacks.expected_behavior: The targeted sleep process loads the fake.so library without terminating; the process continues running normally.

attacks.description: Writes a NOP sled directly into the memory of a running sleep process via the /proc/<pid>/mem interface, representing a direct memory injection technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified bytes are written into the target process's memory; this may alter process behavior or cause instability.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign text file from a remote HTTP server using certutil, demonstrating application‑layer protocol (HTTP GET) traffic.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file benign.txt is saved to the user's temporary directory; network traffic shows an HTTP GET to example.com.

attacks.description: Uses BITS (bitsadmin) to pull a file over HTTP, representing a more stealthy application‑layer protocol download.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS creates a background transfer job named 'myjob' and stores payload.exe in the temp folder; HTTP GET traffic is generated.

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell one‑liner that POSTs data to a remote HTTP endpoint, emulating beacon or exfiltration over an application‑layer protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: A POST request is sent to http://example.com/collect with the body 'data=hello'; no files are written to disk.

attacks.description: Basic use of HTTP GET to exfiltrate the host's hostname to a remote server using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command makes a silent HTTP request to the specified URL; the server would receive a query parameter containing the hostname.

attacks.description: Intermediate reverse shell over a raw TCP connection using netcat (nc).
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat connects to attacker.example.com on port 4444 and, upon connection, spawns a bash shell whose I/O is forwarded over the TCP channel.

attacks.description: Advanced encrypted C2 channel using socat to create a TLS‑wrapped reverse shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Socat establishes a TLS connection to attacker.example.com on port 443, then spawns a bash shell with a pseudo‑terminal; all shell I/O is encrypted over the TLS channel.

attacks.description: Creates a plain text file, encodes it to Base64 using certutil, then decodes it back, demonstrating simple file content obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file plain.txt containing 'HelloWorld' is created in %TEMP%, then encoded.txt (Base64) is generated, and finally decoded.txt is recreated with the original content.

attacks.description: Runs a Base64‑encoded PowerShell command that writes an obfuscated (reversed) string to a file, illustrating command‑level obfuscation via encoded payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Base64 string is decoded to the PowerShell command `Set-Content -Path "$env:TEMP\obf.txt" -Value "dlroW olleH"`, which creates obf.txt in %TEMP% containing the reversed text.

attacks.description: Stores the string "Hello World" as a hex representation, then uses certutil to decode the hex back to the original text, showing obfuscation via hexadecimal encoding.
attacks.expected_behavior: hex.txt contains the hex sequence 48656C6C6F20576F726C64; certutil decodes it to decoded_hex.txt, which contains the original string "Hello World".

attacks.command: echo 'This is a hidden message' > /tmp/hidden_message.txt; base64 /tmp/hidden_message.txt
attacks.description: Creates a hidden message in a file and then encodes it with base64 to obscure its contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file with a hidden message and then encodes the file's contents using base64, making it harder to detect the message's purpose without decoding.

attacks.description: Encrypts a plain text file using AES-256-CBC, obscuring its contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encrypts a plain text file, making its contents unreadable without the decryption key, thus obscuring the information.

attacks.description: Uses steghide to embed a hidden message into an image file, obscuring the message's existence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command hides a message within an image file, making it difficult to detect the message without knowing it's there and how to extract it.

attacks.description: Download a benign test executable from a remote server using certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil writes the file to the %TEMP% directory and outputs a success message indicating the download completed.

attacks.description: Download the test executable and immediately execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is downloaded to %TEMP% and then launched; the benign executable may display a simple message box or exit silently.

attacks.description: Send a crafted HTTP request that mimics exploiting a vulnerable public‑facing web application (e.g., SQL injection).
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell issues the request and receives an HTTP response; no files are written to disk, and the command completes with a status code output.

attacks.description: Basic: Send a GET request to a potentially vulnerable web application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends an HTTP GET request to the specified URL, potentially exploiting a vulnerability in the web application.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Send a POST request to a potentially vulnerable web application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends an HTTP POST request to the specified URL, potentially exploiting a vulnerability in the web application.

attacks.description: Advanced: Send a GET request with a custom User-Agent header to a potentially vulnerable web application
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends an HTTP GET request to the specified URL with a custom User-Agent header, potentially exploiting a vulnerability in the web application.

attacks.description: Compress a single test file into a ZIP archive using PowerShell's built‑in Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\test.txt if it does not exist, then produces %TEMP%\archive.zip containing that file.

attacks.description: Create a temporary collection folder, place a sample file inside, and archive the folder with tar.exe into a .tar file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces %TEMP%\collected.tar containing the %APPDATA%\Collected directory and its data.txt file.

attacks.command: cmd /c "echo FileOne > \"%TEMP%\\data1.txt\" && echo FileTwo > \"%TEMP%\\data2.txt\" && makecab /D CompressionType=LZX /D CompressionMemory=21 \"%TEMP%\\data1.txt\" \"%TEMP%\\data1.cab\" && makecab /D CompressionType=LZX /D CompressionMemory=21 \"%TEMP%\\data2.txt\" \"%TEMP%\\data2.cab\" && copy /b \"%TEMP%\\data1.cab\"+\"%TEMP%\\data2.cab\" \"%TEMP%\\collected.cab\""
attacks.description: Create two sample files, compress each with makecab.exe, then concatenate the resulting CAB files into a single archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates %TEMP%\data1.cab and %TEMP%\data2.cab, then combines them into %TEMP%\collected.cab, effectively archiving both data files.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of a collected data directory using tar with gzip compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/data_archive.tar.gz containing the contents of /tmp/collected_data.

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving using zip, recursively adding files while excluding temporary files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates /tmp/data_archive.zip with all files from /tmp/collected_data except those matching *.tmp.

attacks.description: Advanced archiving of privileged system log files, requiring root access to read the logs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/logs_archive.tar.gz containing the specified log files, demonstrating collection of sensitive data.

attacks.description: Open mspaint to manually capture the screen
attacks.expected_behavior: mspaint opens, allowing manual screen capture

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save("$env:TEMP\screenshot.png")"
attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and save to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The screen is captured and saved as a PNG file in the TEMP directory

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save("$env:APPDATA\screenshot.png")"
attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell, saving to the APPDATA directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The screen is captured and saved as a PNG file in the APPDATA directory

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the entire screen and save it to a file named screenshot.png in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Capture a specific region of the screen and save it to a file named screenshot.png
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will prompt the user to select a region of the screen to capture and save it to a file named screenshot.png in the current working directory.

attacks.description: Capture the screen of all displays and save each screenshot to a separate file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will capture the screen of all displays and save each screenshot to a separate file named screenshot_<display_number>.png in the current working directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$temp='$env:TEMP\phish_test.txt'; Set-Content -Path $temp -Value 'This is a test attachment for phishing simulation.' -Force; Send-MailMessage -From 'attacker@example.com' -To 'victim@example.com' -Subject 'Important Update' -Body 'Please see the attached document.' -SmtpServer 'smtp.example.com' -Attachments $temp"
attacks.description: Creates a benign text file and sends it as an email attachment to simulate a phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: A test email is sent to the specified recipient with the created text file attached; no actual malicious content is delivered.

attacks.description: Creates a shortcut on the Desktop named like a PDF (Invoice.pdf.lnk) that actually launches Notepad, mimicking a phishing lure via a deceptive file type.
attacks.expected_behavior: A shortcut file appears on the Desktop; when double‑clicked it opens Notepad, demonstrating the user‑interaction aspect of phishing.

attacks.description: Stores a base64‑encoded harmless PowerShell script in a temporary file, decodes it with certutil, and executes it, replicating the hidden‑payload aspect of phishing attachments.
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded script runs and prints "Phishing payload executed" to the console; no harmful actions are performed.

attacks.command: echo "Please review the attached report: http://malicious.example.com/login" | mail -s "Important Update" user@example.com
attacks.description: Sends a basic phishing email containing a malicious link using the built‑in 'mail' command.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is delivered to user@example.com with subject 'Important Update' and body containing the malicious URL.

attacks.command:
printf "
Username:
Password:
" > $HOME/phish.html && echo "Please see attached file for account verification." | mutt -s "Account Verification Required" -a $HOME/phish.html -- user@example.com
attacks.description: Creates a fake login HTML page and sends it as an attachment via 'mutt' to simulate a more convincing phishing email.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email with subject 'Account Verification Required' and attachment 'phish.html' is sent to user@example.com; the attachment contains a deceptive login form.

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' | sendmail -t To: user@example.com Subject: Security Alert MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="BOUNDARY" --BOUNDARY Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8" Your account has been flagged. Please click the link below to verify: http://malicious.example.com/verify --BOUNDARY Content-Type: text/html; charset="UTF-8"

Your account has been flagged. Please verify now.

--BOUNDARY-- EOF
attacks.description: Uses 'sendmail' to craft a raw MIME email with both plain‑text and HTML parts, including a tracking pixel, representing an advanced phishing delivery technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: A multipart email is sent to user@example.com; the HTML part displays a phishing message with a clickable link and an invisible tracking pixel, while the plain‑text part contains the same malicious URL.
